creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture
description: black and white landscape; various ragged, cone-shaped mountains dominate the scene; small pagoda with out building and two trees in middle ground; trees top rock formations in foreground near bottom; inscription URC
inscription: 雲起山叱勅　泉流石亦鳴　年来仙窟裏　自覚道心生 (The cloud rises and the mountain screams and scolds; / The spring flows and the rocks resonate. / I have been living in this immortal’s cave for years, / Naturally I cannot help but to entertain a religious feeling. / At the end of the winter 1914, I painted and inscribed this at the High Pines Inn.) [Masato Nishimura]
markings: poem UR red seal: 无心 {mushin} [mushin #2]; poem LL red seals: 字曰子徳 {azana iwaku Shitoku}, 静處 {seisho} [seisho #3]; LLC red seal: 拙居 {sekkyo}
signed: 甲寅孟冬寫於高松客舎并題古道人田耕 {kinoe-tora mōtō sha oite Takamatsu kyakusha narabini dai Kodōjin Denkō} (December 1914, drawn at a lodging in Takamatsu and title by Kodōjin Denkō)
text: This work offers compelling interpretations of familiar Chinese themes and pictorial conventions. The ridges of the mountains, nested like the layers of an onion, reference the landscapes of Wang Hui (1632–1717) and Wang Shimin (1592–1680). The bizarre shapes and heavy “Mi dots,” wet brush strokes used to depict misty mountains, imbue the scene with a brooding animism reflected in the accompanying poem: The cloud rises and the mountain screams and scolds; The spring flows and the rocks resonate. I have been living in this immortal’s cave for years, Naturally I cannot help but to entertain a religious feeling. At the end of the winter 1914, I painted and inscribed this at the High Pines Inn. (translated by Masato Nishimura)
title: Landscape after Mi Fu
